comments: For all k in A014224, 3^(k-1)*(3^k-2) is in this sequence. - _M. F. Hasler_, Apr 25 2012The known examples are all of the form 3^(k-1)*(3^k-2), where 3^k-2 is prime (cf. A014224). Conversely, from sigma(3^(k-1)*p)=(3^k-1)/2*(p+1) it is immediate that 2*sigma(n)=3n+1 for such numbers, i.e., they are 2-hyperperfect. (This is "form 3" with p=3 in McCranie's paper.) - _M. F. Hasler_, Apr 25 2012a(6) > 4*10^12. - _Donovan Johnson_, Nov 20 2012
